choices.text: Sensorineural deafness occurs as a complication in 80% of patients.
Tympanostomy tubes are usually required for treatment
Intracranial spread of infection complicates the clinical course.
Gram negative organisms are grown routinely in culture aspirate.

questions.text: A 20 year old female patient presented with a complain of heaviness inside left ear and decreased hearing since 3 months. Endoscopic picture of the affected ear is shown below. Impedence audiometry was done suggestive of type b curve. Which of the following statements is true for this condition?
questions.solution:
• Based on the endoscopic picture and type b curve on impedence audiometry the diagnosis in this case is serous otitis media.
  • It is defined as collection of sterile fluid in the middle ear. So on aspiration of this fluid no organisms are usually isolated hence option d is not true.
  • Also since it's sterile fluid collection the chances of bone erosion and developing an intracranial abscess is negligible thus option c is not true.
  • The collected fluid in the middle ear impairs with the function of impedence matching of the middle ear and usually does not effect the inner ear. Thus it leads to conductive deafness. Hence option A is also not true.
  • It's management primarily includes antihistamines, and decongestant.
  • But if the condition does not resolve even after 3 months than Myringotomy is performed followed by placement of grommet tube or tympanostomy tube to maintain ventilation.

Tag 1: Ear, serous otitis media.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra, 8th Edition, Page Number: 75, 76.

choices.text: Topical antibiotics and decongestant for 4 weeks

questions.text: A 40 year old male patient presents with foul smelling ear discharge. Discharge was scanty in nature, patient also experience vertigo intermittently. HRCT temporal bone was done which is suggestive of cholesteatoma in epitympanum and mesotympanum with erosion of incus. On endoscopy the tympanic membrane appeared as the picture given below. Most appropriate Next step in management is?
questions.solution:
• The picture shown above is suggestive of attic retraction pocket with cholesteatoma flakes.
  • Cholesteatoma is presence of keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium in any part of temporal bone where it is usually not present. Eg middle ear, mastoid, petrous Apex.
  • In its basal layer cholesteatoma has got enzymes like collagenase and acid phosphatase which cause the bony erosion, helping the middle ear infection to reach the surrounding areas leading to various complications.
  • Patient present here with scant, painless and foul smelling discharge because of otitis and bone erosion by cholesteatoma and infection with anaerobic organism.
  • The main management of unsafe CSOM is mastoid exploration with removal of disease from the mastoid, followed by removal of disease from middle ear.

Option A is wrong because discharge in unsafe otitis media is mainly because of bone erosion hence medical management with local and systemic antibiotics does not have much affect on drying of discharge.

Option C only Myringoplasty is not sufficient in eradicating the disease from middle ear and mastoid cavity.

Option D radical mastoidectomy is indicated in extensive cholesteatoma following unsafe csom with dead ear.

Unresectable cholesteatoma extending upto petrous Apex, promontory cochlear fistula.

Tag 1: Ear, management of cholesteatoma.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra, 8th Edition, Page Number: 86, 87.

choices.text: Ear is pulled upwards, backwards, syringe jet posterosuperiorly.
Ear is pulled downwards, backwards, syringe jet anteriosuperiorly.
Ear is pulled upwards, forwards, syringe jet anteriosuperiorly.
Ear is pulled downwards and forwards, syringe jet posterosuperiorly.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the procedure given below?
questions.solution:
• The procedure shown in the picture given above is called Ear syringing.
  • In this procedure the pinna is pulled upwards, backwards, water is injected at body temperature through a syringe into the EAC along the posterosuperior wall.
  • The pressure of water builds up in EAC and wax comes out.

Complications of syringing:

1) Vertigo 2) rupture of TM 3) Reactivation of otitis media.

Contraindications: acute inflammatory conditions of external or middle ear.

2) perforation of TM 3) presence of a grommet 4) History of ear surgery.

Tag 1: Ear, External ear disorders.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra, 8th Edition, Page Number:63.

questions.text: A 20 year old female patient presented with complain of inability to close right eye, Deviation of angle of mouth, Dripping of saliva from angle of mouth. The following test was performed in the patient picture given below. Function of Which of the following nerve is tested here?
questions.solution:
The patient in this case is suffering from Facial palsy. The test shown in the figure given above is called schirmer test.

The first branch of facial nerve is Greater petrosal nerve. It arises from geniculate ganglion and goes to sphenopalatine ganglion and gives secretomotor fibers to lacrimal, nasal and palatine glands. It's section leads to dry eye which can be tested by schirmer test with help of what man filter paper.

Tag 1: Ear, Facial nerve.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition, page number:116, 117.

Image reference: American academy of ophthalmology.

questions.text:
A 18 year old male patient presented with complain of unilateral nasal obstruction. Xray of nose and nasopharynx lateral view shows presence of Dodd's sign. Picture given below.


What is the most probable diagnosis based on this?
questions.solution:
Antrochoanal polyp presents as unilateral nasal mass which occur following obstruction of osteomeatal complex.

The best investigation of AC polyp is CT scan of nose and Paranasal sinus.

It shows a mass arising from maxillary antrum and extending into posterior choanae.

Ct or Xray lateral view of nose and nasopharynx will show a column of air between the mass and the pharyngeal wall. This is known as crescent sign or Dodd sign.

This sign will be absent in the mass arising from pharyngeal wall such as angiofibroma, Nasopharyngeal carcinoma and adenoid hypertrophy.

Tag 1 : Nose, Nasal polyps

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition, page number:200.

Image reference: Applied radiology website.

choices.text: It is caused by fungus rhinosporidium
Should be managed by excision with cautery at base

questions.text: A 40 year old male patient presents with right sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis. On examination, mulberry mass with white dots is seen in the right nostril. Which of the Following is true about this disease ?
questions.solution:
Based on the picture and clinical presentation the diagnosis is Rhinosporidiosis.

It is a protozoan disease caused by protozoa Rhinosporidium seeberi. It is prevalent in south India and it is caused by bathing in ponds frequented by cattles.

Clinical features: bloody nasal discharge, obstruction, red polypoidal mass mulberry or strawberry mass with white dots.

Biopsy is investigation of choice.

Treatment is surgical excision with cauterization of the base, Dapsone post operatively.

Tag 1 : Nose, Granulomatous conditions

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition, page number: 185.

Image reference: The new England journal of medicine.

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient presented with history of nasal blockage for 6 months. On examination the patient had a nasal mass with mucinous discharge. The CT scan is showing double density sign. What is the most probable diagnosis based on the CT scan given below?
questions.solution:
The CT scan picture shown above shows haziness of the maxillary sinus and mass in the left nasal cavity without any bony erosion.

The CT scan also shows heterogeneous density in the mass known as double density sign. This is characteristic of Allergic fungal rhinitis.

Maxillary carcinoma will show bony erosion in CT scan. Antrochoanal polyp presents as unilateral nasal mass which is purulent in nature and not mucinous.

Bent and Kuhn criteria of Allergic fungal rhinitis are.

  1. Type 1 hypersensitivity is raised.
  2. Nasal polyps, positive fungal stain.
  3. Biopsy showing fungal elements, allergic mucin.
  4. CT showing hazy sinus with heterogenous appearance.

Tag 1 : Nose, Sinusitis and complications.

Reference: Diseases of Ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition, page number:184.

Image reference: Radiopedia website.

choices.text: It also presents with lateral gaze palsy involving lateral rectus muscle
It occurs because of dilatation of mucous glands of sinuses
It is a subperiosteal abscess involving frontal sinus
Periorbital oedema and conjunctival chemosis may develop.

questions.text: A 60 year old male patient presented with complain of soft doughy and inflamed swelling on the forehead. Picture given below. Patient is known case of diabetes and he is also a known case of chronic rhinitis and sinusitis. Which of the following statements about this condition is true?
questions.solution:
• Patient is a known case of chronic rhinitis and sinusitis. The swelling is soft, doughy and inflamed. The diagnosis in this case is Potts puffy tumour.
  • Osteomyelitis following frontal sinusitis affects only the anterior table of the frontal bone since presence of marrow is limited to the anterior table. It is seen mainly in adults since frontal sinus is not fully developed in childrens.
  • The subperiosteal abscess following Osteomyelitis of frontal bone presents externally as a soft doughy swelling known as Potts puffy tumour.
  • Management includes Surgical drainage of the abscess and removal of necrotic bone after elevating the perichondrium of frontal sinus.
  • Lateral gaze palsy, periorbital edema, conjunctival chemosis are the features of cavernous sinus thrombosis hence these options were wrong.
  • Dilatation of mucous glands of sinuses is seen in Thus this option is also wrong.

Tag 1: Nose, Chronic sinusitis complications.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra, 8th Edition, Page Number: 232.

questions.text: A 7 year old child presents with complain of severe throat pain, fever since 2 days. He also developed trismus since 1 day. On examination of oral cavity left side tonsil was pushed medially. Picture Is given below. The best treatment in this condition is?
questions.solution:
• Based on the clinical picture shown above it is suggestive of peritonsillar abscess. It is also known as Quinsy.
  • The peritonsillar space lies between capsule of tonsil and superior constrictor muscle. Any abscess in this space is called peritonsillar abscess.
  • It usually spreads from Tonsils. Mainly caused by mixed aerobic (Group A beta hemolytic streptococcus) and anaerobic organisms.
  • Clinical features includes painful swallowing, trismus, hot potato voice, pain in ear fever, malaise.

Management: Incision and drainage is the mainstay of treatment. The incision is given just lateral to where a vertical line drawn from anterior border of anterior pillar meets a horizontal line passing through base of uvula.

Antibiotics mostly beta lactum group along with metronidazole is given to cover aerobes and anaerobes respectively.

Tonsillectomy is performed after 6 weeks of episode.

Tag 1: pharynx and oral cavity, Tonsil and Quinsy.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra, 8th edition, page number: 311.

choices.text: It is always a cellulitis and not an abscess
It involves the submandibular and sublingual glands
It spreads through tissue spaces and not through lymphatic.

questions.text: A 30 year old female patient presented with complain of pain and swelling over floor of mouth, bilateral submandibular region. The entire region was tender and inflamed. Patient gave past history of tooth extraction. Patient also has uncontrolled diabetes. Picture given below. All of the following are diagnostic criteria for this condition except?
questions.solution:
• In the above condition the swelling is involving bilateral submandibular region. It developed following dental extraction.
  • Patient also has uncontrolled diabetes. It is involving floor of mouth. All these points leads to diagnosis of Ludwig's abscess.

There are four Goldring s criteria to diagnose Ludwig's abscess.

  • It is always cellulitis and not an If an abscess is present it is known as submandibular abscess and not Ludwig's angina.
  • It is always bilateral
  • It spreads through tissue space and not through lymphatic.
  • It does not involve the submandibular and sublingual glands.

Management: Incision and drainage A horizontal incision is kept 2 to 3 cm below the lower border of mandible extending from angle of mandible to the other.

Antibiotics covering both Aerobes and anaerobes.

Tag 1: pharynx and oral cavity. Deep neck space abscess

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra, 8th Edition, Page Number: 310.

questions.text: A 35 year old female patient known case of malignant condition of salivary gland. She underwent submandibular gland excision. His post operative histopathology showed presence of squamous, mucus and basaloid cells. The squamous cells forms solid nests. The mucous cells forms solid masses or line cysts. Mucin stains were positive. Picture given below. What is the most probable diagnosis based on this?
questions.solution:
The microscopic picture of Mucoepidermoid carcinoma includes:

  • The most common cell type present are squamous cells, mucus cells cuboidal cells and basaloid cells.
  • The squamous cells forms solid nests and it's component often predominates in high grade tumors.
  • The mucous cells forms solid masses or line cysts. They predominates in low grade tumors.
  • Intermediate cells are usually small with dark staining nuclei but can be larger with a clear cytoplasm.

Clinical features: Slow growing tumor painless growth. Well circumscribed. Mostly seen in parotid gland, sometimes in submandibular gland. Mixed epidermis and mucus secreting carcinoma.

Tag 1: Pharynx and neck, salivary gland disorder.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra, 8th Edition, Page Number: 276.

choices.text: Symptoms are predominantly caused by involvement of subglottis.
X-ray is showing the thumb sign.

questions.text: A 4 year old male child presented with complain of fever, inspiratory stridor, and barking cough. His X ray neck AP view was performed. Picture of the x-ray is given below. Which of the following is true about the condition?
questions.solution:
• The sign shown in the x-ray given above is steeple sign. It is seen in laryngo-tracheo-bronchitisor
  • It involves larynx mainly subglottis, leading to subglottis oedema and progress to trachea and bronchi.
  • Clinical features includes gradual onset fever, barking cough, hoarseness and stridor.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by x-ray neck AP view which shows subglottis and upper trachea to be narrowed.
  • It appears like inverted V resembling steeple of a church. Hence known as steeple sign or pencil tip sign.
  • Management includes humidification, decongestant, local and systemic steroids. Intubation or tracheostomy if necessary.

Tag 1: larynx infection of larynx

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra, 8th Edition, Page  Number:339.

choices.text: Most common cause of stridor in new-born

questions.text: A 6 month old baby presented with complain of stridor. The stridor was inspiratory in nature and get aggravated on crying and sleeping in supine position, and it gets relieved on making child prone. Laryngoscopic examination was done picture given below. Which of the following is not true about this condition?
questions.solution:
• Based on the clinical features and picture the diagnosis is laryngomalacia.
  • It is the most common congenital anomaly of the larynx and also the most common cause of stridor in infants.
  • Main presentation is of stridor which is inspiratory in nature and peaks around 6 months of age. The stridor worsens on crying and in supine position and improves in prone position.
  • Laryngoscopy examination reveals curled up Epiglottis or omega shaped Epiglottis. The arytenoids and the AE folds appears flabby
  • Management: As the larynx grows all the redundant tissue is taken up and the stridor disappears by 2 years of age. So management is by conservative by reassurance.
  • Rarely excision of excessive redundant tissue is done called supraglottoplasty.

Tag 1: larynx congenital deformities

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra, 8th Edition, Page Number:344.

choices.text: Involve whole of the membranous part of the vocal cords
Patient has a low pitch voice
Voice rest and Corticosteroids are the mainstay of management

questions.text: A 35 year old male patient presented with complain of hoarseness of voice. He was a chronic smoker. His endoscopy examination reveals following features. Picture given below. Which of the following statements about this condition is not true?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and symptoms the diagnosis in this case is Rienke s oedema.

This is a chronic and irreversible oedema of the Rienke s space. It involves sub mucosal space of the membranous true vocal cords along their free medial margin.

It can occur due to any chronic irritation of larynx most commonly due to smoking hence also known as smokers larynx.

Other irritants such as voice abuse, acid reflux and post nasal drip can also cause this.

Patient presents with low pitch voice, effortful speaking and hoarseness.

Diffuse symmetrical pale swelling is seen on the free edges of both the vocal cords.

Tag 1 : Larynx, speech disorders

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition, page number:353.

Image reference: Voice surgeon website.

questions.text: A 4 year old child presented with the history of accidently ingesting/ inhaling a coin. His X-ray AP and lateral view are given. Based on the X-ray what is the site of lodgement of the coin?
questions.solution:
In The above X-ray the foreign body shadow appears to be linear in the AP view and Round on the lateral view which is suggestive of foreign body to be inside Trachea.

In this X-ray air shadow of the Trachea can also be seen and the foreign body appears inside this shadow which further confirms the findings.

Foreign body shadow in oesophagus appears Round on AP view and linear on lateral view plus the foreign body appears behind the shadow of trachea.

Foreign body in cricopharynx also appears Round in AP view and linear on lateral view. The position is much higher than the shadow of trachea.

Other clinical features suggesting Foreign body inside trachea includes sudden onset of wheeze, expiratory stridor, atelectasis of involved lung.

Management includes Removal of Foreign body through bronchoscopy.

Tag 1 : larynx, foreign body

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edition, page number:375 376.

Image reference: Radiopedia.
